items.question: In which circumstance is a controller NOT required, prior to processing, to carry out a data protection impact assessment?
choices: When the processing involves automated profiling that produces legal effects or similarly significantly affects individuals
When the processing has a legal basis in Union or Member State law and an impact assessment was already carried out as part of the general assessment accompanying the adoption of that law
When the processing is performed on a large scale of special categories of personal data
When the controller has sought the advice of the designated data protection officer before starting the processing
review_reasons: Exactly four answer choices are provided.
Exactly one correct answer is indicated (index 1).

The stated correct option (choice 2) correctly reflects the GDPR exception that a DPIA is not required where processing is based on Union or Member State law and an assessment was already carried out as part of the legislative/adoption process, so other choices are appropriately DPIA triggers or misconceptions (automated profiling with legal/similar significant effects, large-scale processing of special categories, and merely consulting the DPO do not remove the DPIA requirement).
The question text contains no article numbers or citations.

The content is not a near-copy of reference texts (similarity metric provided is low), and the question requires specific regulatory knowledge without being trivial, consistent with medium difficulty.

items.question: Which of the following items is NOT required to be included in the record of processing activities that a controller must maintain?
choices: The purposes of the processing and the categories of data subjects and personal data involved
The legal basis for each processing activity carried out by the controller
Details of transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations, including any safeguards
Where possible, envisaged time limits for erasure of the different categories of data and a general description of technical and organisational security measures
review_reasons: The indicated correct answer (index 1: "The legal basis for each processing activity carried out by the controller") is correct — GDPR records of processing activities list purposes, categories of data subjects and personal data, recipients/transfers and retention and security measures, but do not require listing the legal basis in the controller’s record of processing activities.

Choices 0, 2 and 3 correspond to items explicitly required to be maintained in the controller’s record of processing activities (purposes and categories; transfer details and safeguards; envisaged erasure time limits and security description).
There is exactly one correct answer and exactly four choices, as required.
The question text contains no citation of an article number.
Similarity metrics provided are low, supporting that this is not a near-copy of reference material.
Difficulty is appropriate for medium level: it requires specific knowledge of what the GDPR’s record-keeping obligations include and exclude.
